title: Introduction
body:
With the rise of the internet and social media, we have begun sharing more personal information than at any point in human history. This has had many positive effects and led to scientific discovery and social change. There is a darker side to the sharing of so much information: this information can be used to hack, defraud and attack people and businesses alike.

You may or may not be aware of the threats posed by cybercrime and social engineering. Even when there is awareness, people can still be caught out by hackers and tricksters.

In order to help raise awareness we'll be looking at the following subjects:
instruction:
• What is cybercrime?
  • What is social engineering?
  • How does it work?
  • Why is it so dangerous?
  • How to spot a phishing attack

title: What is Cybercrime?
body: Cybercrime is any criminal activity that involves a computer, networked device or a network. While most cybercrimes are carried out in order to generate profit for the cybercriminals, some cybercrimes are carried out against computers or devices directly to damage or disable them, while others use computers or networks to spread malware, illegal information, images or other materials. Some cybercrimes do both -- i.e., target computers to infect them with viruses, which are then spread to other machines and, sometimes, entire networks.

title: Cybercriminals
body:
You might be wondering what the profile of a cybercriminal might be.

The short answer is: Anyone

Cybercriminals tend to fall into one of several categories:

  • Vandals
  • Blackmailers
  • Thieves
  • Saboteurs
  • State-sponsored hackers
  • Scammers

title: Cybercriminals
body:
The motivations of cybercriminals may not always be the same, but they often use a similar toolset. This allows them to engage in activities such as:

  • International and/or industrial sabotage
  • Accessing restricted systems and infrastructure to steal personal, financial and/or industrial information
  • Locking systems and/or stealing data to hold it for ransom or sell on the black market
  • Trolling/computer vandalism
  • Financial extortion or gain

title: What Do Cybercriminals Want?
body: There are many reasons that a hacker or group of hackers may seek to access our information. None of them good.
instruction: Select the next and back arrows to find out more what cybercriminals want.
mobileInstruction: Select the next and back arrows followed by the plus icon to find out more.

_items.title: For Financial Gain
_items.body:
This is the number one reason for people to engage in hacking and social engineering

If the cybercriminal can gain access to data they could sell the information on to other criminals for a profit. That information could be used for fraud, identity theft, extortion or blackmail.

_items.title: To Steal Identities
_items.body: Having unauthroised access to personal information may provide the means for cybercriminals to represent themselves as yourself or someone else. This could lead to fraud and theft.

_items.title: Espionage
_items.body: Some cybercriminals might be working for a foreign government or working for a political or terrorise organisation that seeks to disrupt industry or vital national infrastructure.

_items.title: For Fun
_items.body:
There have, in recent years, been examples of cyber attacks that don't appear to have any clear motive beyond boosting the ego of the cybercriminals behind them.

The attackes claim "bragging rights" whilst causing disruption amongst those who use the services that they attack.

title: The Definition of Cyber Crime
body: Criminal activities carried out by means of computers and/or the internet.

title: The Definition of Social Engineering
body:
The art of manipulating people into performing actions, providing access, and divulging confidential information.

Social Engineering will often have non-cyber elements also.

title: The Social Engineer's Toolkit
body:
A skilled social engineer doesn’t have too much trouble talking their way into places where they shouldn’t be.

Given the nature of A-Gas’ business, it is imperative to ensure that they have more trouble than it’s worth trying to get into our sites and systems.
instruction: A well-seasoned social engineer may employ some or all of the tools below:

back.title: A Phone

title: Types of Malware
body:
You can use the accordion component to present learners with a series of headings which, once selected, expand to reveal associated text. Select each of the headings below to find out more about how accordions can be used.

These components can be either single or spanned. If spanned they can also contain a graphic.
instruction: Select the headings to find out more.

_items.title: Virus
_items.body:
A computer virus operates in a manner not too dissimilar from a biological virus. It infects the host computer, hijacking some or all of the computer’s functions. A Virus might destroy data or look for something valuable and relay that on to a third party to exploit.

Some of the types of information that a virus might look for are listed here:

  • User names and passwords
  • Credit and debit card information
  • Names and addresses
  • Other personal or business information

_items.title: Trojan
_items.body:
A Trojan takes its name the trojan horse which the Greeks used to capture the city of Troy.

Like its namesake, a Trojan is malware that is either disguised as benign software or is hidden within a file or document.

The Trojan’s effects depend upon its design and can range from destruction or theft of data, to enabling remote access to the system and networks that the system might be connected to.

_items.title: Ransomware
_items.body:
Ransomware, as the name might suggest, is malware that holds the victim's computer to ransom.

There are several ways that they might achieve this, but as usual, it normally begins with someone downloading and opening an infected file. Once the software is installed it may then lock the user out and even encrypt the users hard drive, preventing further access unless a ransom is paid.

If a ransom is paid there is no guarantee that the device will be unlocked.

_items.title: Worms
_items.body:
Worms spread through self-replication like certain types of worm.

Worms are often spread via emails. The victim might receive an email with an attachment containing the worm. Once the worm has been downloaded and has infected the system it hijacks the user’s email account, sending copies of itself to the victim's contacts, spreading the infection further.

Worms can be differentiated from viruses in the sense that they are self-replicating, i.e. they are actively spread by the worm itself rather than accidentally being replicated by a user.

_items.title: Botnet
_items.body:
A botnet is a group of computers connected in a coordinated fashion for malicious purposes. Each computer in a botnet is called a bot. These bots form a network of compromised computers, which are controlled by a third party and used to transmit malware, spam or overwhelm a web server in a denial of service attack.

People may install botnet software by accident. It then remains dormant until the attacker decides to activate it.

A botnet may also be known as a "zombie army".

_items.title: Keylogger
_items.body:
There are two main different types of keyloggers:

  • Hardware keyloggers
  • Software keyloggers

Hardware keyloggers are often designed so that you can plug a keyboard into it and then plug the keyboard, with keylogger, into a computer. This requires physical access to the system being attacked. The keyboard appears to work as expected, but the keylogger will record every key that is typed.

Software keyloggers act in a similar way. The main difference is that they can be put on a computer remotely and can send the results back to the attacker via the internet.

title: How Does Social Engineering Work?
body:
There are two main different types of keyloggers:

  • Hardware keyloggers
  • Software keyloggers

Hardware keyloggers are often designed so that you can plug a keyboard into it and then plug the keyboard, with keylogger, into a computer. This requires physical access to the system being attacked. The keyboard appears to work as expected, but the keylogger will record every key that is typed.

Software keyloggers act in a similar way. The main difference is that they can be put on a computer remotely and can send the results back to the attacker via the internet.

_captions.text: ...But to hold it together when everyone else would understand if you fell apart - that's true strength.
I've got a really bad headache

title: Media
body:
Sometimes we need to make use of rich media to really drive home a point, bring a complex subject to life or just let audio to literally do the talking. This is when the media component comes to the fore.

Component can be either single or spanned.
instruction: Select the play button to start the video.

_transcript.inlineTranscriptBody: Responsive design means you can create a course once but view it on a wide range of browsers, devices or operating systems. This is achieved by using fluid layouts to ensure the presentation of content is tailored to suit the size of the screen. This means you can start a course on your laptop and finish it later on your mobile or tablet. We call it Adapt

title: Watch a Social Engineer Hack into a Company
displayTitle: Watch a Social Engineer Hack into a Company
body: Social engineers, or people hackers, specialize in getting you to share information you shouldn't -- like personal details that could lead to a password being stolen.

title: 5 Types of Social Engineering Attacks
body: As mentioned previously, there are many different ways in which an attacker can perform a social engineering operation. Although it is difficult to suggest what a typical social engineering attack might look like, some of the more common methods used are explained below:
instruction: Select the headings to find out more.

_items.title: Phishing
_items.body: Malicious email or website disguised as an authentic one, e.g. "customerservice@nalwest.com"

_items.title: Baiting
_items.body: The offer of something desirable in exchange for information, e.g. "Sign up to win!"

_items.title: Quid Pro Quo
_items.body: The offer of a "free" service which serves as a means to request private or personal information.

_items.title: Pre-Texting
_items.body: Impersonating a colleague, friend, family member or authority figure in order to be able to approach the target under the "pre-text" of being someone else.

_items.title: Piggybacking/Tailgating
_items.body: When an unauthorised person follows an authorised person into a restricted area, either physically or electronically (e.g. remote screen share, trojans, etc).

title: When a Social Engineering Attack Works
displayTitle: When a Social Engineering Attack Works
body: Social engineering attacks take place all the time all over the world and, suffice to say, many of them are successful. When an attack is successful it can be devastating financially and embarrassing.
instruction: Below are three very public examples of what can happen when these types of attacks are successful.
mobileInstruction: Select the next and back arrows followed by the plus icon to find out more.

_items.title: Sony Pictures Hack (2014)
_items.body:
This is the number one reason for people to engage in hacking and social engineering

If the cybercriminal can gain access to data they could sell the information on to other criminals for a profit. That information could be used for fraud, identity theft, extortion or blackmail.In 2014 Sony Pictures (the production company behind many Hollywood blockbusters), was hacked.

The hackers were able to make off with such a large amount of data by working with or tricking Sony staff. It's still unclear exactly what happened, but here are the rough details.

_items.title: How They Got Access
_items.body:
There is still speculation about exactly how they got insider access, but the two main theories are:

  • A disgruntled employee provided access intentionally to the hackers
  • A former IT employee had been successfully compromised in a malware phishing attack giving the hackers broad access to the Sony Pictures network

    • Once on Sony Picture's network, they spread more malware which found and stole other passwords and sent this information back to the hackers.

_items.title: What Happened Next
_items.body:
Part of the demands made against Sony Pictures was that they pull a movie, The Interview, which mocked the life of North Korean leader, Kim Jong Un. Sony Pictures was threatened with a terrorist attack which drew the attention of the FBI.

Sony bowed to the pressure and pulled the movie just before release, losing millions of dollars in revenue and suffering a great deal of international embarrassment.

_items.title: The Consequences
_items.body: This exemplifies so many of the difficulties that we face with cybersecurity. You can have people on both the inside and outside of an organisation looking to damage it. It also shows the length of time a dedicated individual or team will wait before executing an attack.

title: Spotting a Phishing Website
body:
You can add interactivity to an image by using the hot graphic. This component allows you to position icons over an image. When an icon is selected, content associated with its corresponding location is displayed in a window over the image. This component will fall back to a narrative when viewed on mobile.

This component is always spanned.
instruction: Select the icons to find out more.

_items.title: HTTPS
_items.body: This is display text 1 which we have associated with the tablet image on the desktop.

_items.title: Dodgy Link
_items.body: This is display text 2 which we have linked to the smartphone image.

_items.title: Bad Links
_items.body: This is display text 3 which we’ve located over the laptop so you would expect the content to be about PCs.

title: Summary
body: Well done. You've reached the end of this lesson and should now be familiar with various types of malware, cybercriminals, and the social engineering life cycle.

title: Multiple Choice Question
body: In what year was the first recorded instance of a large scale assessment that consists solely of multiple choice questions?
instruction: Choose one or more options and select Submit.

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct:
Correct feedback text.

That’s correct. The first large assessment to consist solely of the multiple choice question type was the Army Alpha test, used from 1917 to evaluate U.S. military recruits in the First World War.

Source: Wikipedia

Component facts: Multiple Choice Questions (or MCQs) are a tried and tested method for presenting learners with a simple text-based question. Component is either single or spanned.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect feedback text.

That’s not right. The first large assessment to consist solely of the multiple choice question type was the Army Alpha test, used from 1917 to evaluate U.S. military recruits in the First World War.

Source: Wikipedia

Component facts: Multiple Choice Questions (or MCQs) are a tried and tested method for presenting learners with a simple text-based question. Component is either single or spanned.

title: Graphical Multiple Choice Question
body: The graphical multiple choice question is an alternative to the standard MCQ, and allows you to ask a question and present the options as graphics (with accompanying captions). This component is always spanned.

_feedback.title: Feedback

Correct feedback text.

That’s correct. Option 2 is what we were looking for!

_incorrect.final:

Sorry, that’s not right. In fact Option 2 is what we were looking for (the clue was in the instruction text!).

title: Text Input
body: Can you name one of the three companies that established Adapt as a community led Open Source project?
instruction: Input your answer and select Submit.

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct:
Correct answer feedback.

That’s correct. The Adapt Open Source project was established by Kineo, Learning Pool and Sponge. At the time of writing, there are a total of nine official collaborators.

Component facts: Text input components let learners enter their own answers, which is great for questions that require a bit more flexibility, like those with answers that could be written as both full words and numbers.

title: Matching
body: Can you identify some of the key facts and figures associated with the Adapt Open Source project?
instruction: Choose an option from each dropdown list and select Submit.

_items.text: The Adapt Open Source project was formed in:
Adapt adheres to level 'AA' of the <abbr title='Web Content Accessibility Guidelines'>WCAG</abbr> version 2, but when were these published?
Which of these languages would benefit from using the recent addition of Right To Left (RTL) language support within Adapt?

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct:
Correct answer feedback.

Yes, that’s right. Adapt was established as an Open Source project in 2013. The Web Accessibility Initiative (WAI) published the WCAG 2.0 guidelines in 2008 and Hebrew is the only language of the four shown which reads right to left.

Component facts: The matching component lets you match a series of questions or statements with the corresponding options from the dropdown box. Component is either single or spanned.

_partlyCorrect.final:
Partially correct answer feedback.

That’s partially correct. Adapt was established as an Open Source project in 2013. The Web Accessibility Initiative (WAI) published the WCAG 2.0 guidelines in 2008 and Hebrew is the only language of the four shown which reads right to left.

Component facts: The matching component lets you match a series of questions or statements with the corresponding options from the dropdown box. Component is either single or spanned.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect answer feedback.

Sorry, that’s not right. Adapt was established as an Open Source project in 2013. The Web Accessibility Initiative (WAI) published the WCAG 2.0 guidelines in 2008 and Hebrew is the only language of the four shown which reads right to left.

Component facts: The matching component lets you match a series of questions or statements with the corresponding options from the dropdown box. Component is either single or spanned.

title: Slider
body: Working memory is thought to be responsible for our ability to temporarily hold and manipulate information, but according to a paper by Miller (1956) what ‘magic number’ describes its capacity?
instruction: Drag the slider to make your choice and select Submit.

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct:
Correct answer feedback.

Yes, that’s right. According to Miller’s paper 7 +/- 2 chunks of information was the limited capacity of working memory. Various theories from the field of cognitive psychology such as Miller’s magical number, chunking, the forgetting curve and spaced repetition have all influenced learning theory over the last 50 years or so.

Component facts: The correct answer for a slider component can be an exact number or a range. In this instance we have set the correct answer to a range of 5-9 due to the correct answer being seven plus or minus two. Component is either single or spanned.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect answer feedback.

Sorry, that’s not right. According to Miller’s paper 7 +/- 2 chunks of information was the limited capacity of working memory. Various theories from the field of cognitive psychology such as Miller’s magical number, chunking, the forgetting curve and spaced repetition have all influenced learning theory over the last 50 years or so.

Component facts: The correct answer for a slider component can be an exact number or a range. In this instance we have set the correct answer to a range of 5-9 due to the correct answer being seven plus or minus two. Component is either single or spanned.

title: To scroll or not to scroll?
displayTitle: To scroll or not to scroll?
body: Can you identify a few of the benefits that a vertical scrolling approach offers over the traditional back and next approach?
instruction: Choose one or more options and select Submit.

_items.text: Scrolling is common place on the web and therefore familiar to the learner
Scrolling reduces the need for unnecessary navigation as pages can be as long (or as short) as they need to be
Scrolling helps ensure designs are more mobile friendly
Scrolling means you no longer need to first gain learners attention

title: Scoring bands
body:
The Assessment Results component allows you to specify the assessment pass mark, and provide tailored feedback to as many scoring bands as you wish.

In this short assessment we set the pass mark at 75% or above and provided four scoring bands, each of which has some accompanying feedback. The four scoring bands were:

  • 0-49% (fail)
  • 50-74% (fail)
  • 75-99% (pass)
  • 100% (perfect score)

So, how did you do? Let’s find out.

title: Results
